title: Coordinate Plane Explorer
description: An interactive MicroSim that helps students understand the coordinate plane structure, including quadrants, axes, origin, and point location through hands-on exploration and quiz mode.
subject: Mathematics
prerequisites: Understanding of positive and negative numbers
Ability to read and write ordered pairs
learningObjectives: Identify and label the x-axis, y-axis, and origin on a coordinate plane
Understand the structure and numbering of the four quadrants
Plot points accurately using ordered pairs (x, y)
Determine which quadrant contains a given point
Recognize the sign patterns for coordinates in each quadrant
Use coordinates to describe the location of points on a plane
educationalStandards: CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.6.NS.C.6 - Understand rational numbers as points on the number line and in the coordinate plane
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.6.NS.C.8 - Solve problems by graphing points in all four quadrants
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.6.G.A.3 - Draw polygons in the coordinate plane
author: MicroSim Development Team

controls.label: Point
controls.description: Drag the red point anywhere on the coordinate plane to explore different coordinate positions

controls.label: Enter x
controls.description: Input field to enter the x-coordinate directly

controls.label: Enter y
controls.description: Input field to enter the y-coordinate directly

controls.label: Plot
controls.description: Plot the point at the coordinates entered in the input fields

controls.label: Random Point
controls.description: Generate and plot a random point on the coordinate plane

controls.label: Quiz Mode
controls.description: Toggle quiz mode where students are challenged to plot given coordinates

controls.label: Check Answer
controls.description: Check if the plotted point matches the quiz target (only visible in quiz mode)

controls.label: Quadrant Shading
controls.description: Toggle color-coded shading of the four quadrants

controls.label: Grid Lines
controls.description: Toggle visibility of grid lines for easier point placement

controls.label: Reference Lines
controls.description: Toggle dotted lines from the point to both axes

visualElements: Coordinate grid from -10 to 10 on both axes
Bold axis lines (x-axis and y-axis)
Origin marked with dot and (0, 0) label
Quadrant labels (I, II, III, IV) in Roman numerals
Color-coded quadrant shading (I: light blue, II: light green, III: light yellow, IV: light pink)
Draggable red point with shadow effect
Dotted reference lines from point to axes
Real-time coordinate display with color coding
Quadrant identification display
interactiveFeatures: Drag point to any location on the plane
Smooth animations when plotting new points
Direct coordinate entry via input fields
assessmentOpportunities: Quiz mode tracks correct vs. total attempts
Immediate feedback on coordinate plotting accuracy
Hints provided when answers are incorrect (which coordinate needs adjustment)
Observable student exploration patterns
Exit ticket: Successfully plot 3 points in quiz mode

accessibility.screenReader: Includes describe() function for screen reader support
accessibility.colorBlindSafe: Uses high contrast colors and multiple visual cues beyond color

commonMisconceptions.remedy: Color-coded display always shows x first; mnemonic 'x before y in alphabet'
Quadrant shading visually shows negative regions; incremental practice

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Points on axes belong to quadrants
commonMisconceptions.remedy: Clear 'On x-axis' or 'On y-axis' messages; discussion of quadrant definitions

extensionActivities: Plot points to create geometric shapes

technologyRequirements.devices: Desktop, laptop, tablet (700px width minimum recommended)

cognitiveLoadConsiderations.intrinsic: Coordinate system with four quadrants and signed numbers
cognitiveLoadConsiderations.extraneous: Minimized through clean interface and optional visual aids
cognitiveLoadConsiderations.germane: Focused on coordinate relationships and spatial reasoning

differentiationStrategies: Quadrant shading can be toggled for visual learners
Grid lines assist students who need more structure
Reference lines show explicit connections to axes
Quiz mode provides practice with immediate feedback
Random point generator offers unlimited practice opportunities

title: Expression Parts Explorer
description: An interactive educational MicroSim that helps students identify and understand the different parts of algebraic expressions including coefficients, variables, constants, and terms through color-coding and interactive exploration.
subject: Mathematics - Algebra
creator: Generated with Claude Code
prerequisites: Basic understanding of numbers and arithmetic operations
Familiarity with the concept of variables in algebra
learningObjectives: Identify coefficients, variables, constants, and operations in algebraic expressions
Distinguish between different types of terms in multi-term expressions
Analyze the structure of algebraic expressions of varying complexity
Apply understanding to classify expression parts independently
accessibility: Screen reader support via describe() function

controls.name: New Expression
controls.description: Generates a new random algebraic expression based on the selected complexity level

controls.name: Quiz Mode
controls.description: Toggles quiz mode where users can click on parts to test their understanding without color hints

controls.name: Complexity Level
controls.description: Controls the complexity of generated expressions: Simple (2-3 terms), Medium (3-5 terms with exponents), Complex (4-6 terms with exponents)

controls.name: Show Coefficients
controls.description: Toggles color highlighting of coefficients in blue

controls.name: Show Variables
controls.description: Toggles color highlighting of variables in green

controls.name: Show Constants
controls.description: Toggles color highlighting of constants in orange

controls.name: Highlight Terms
controls.description: Toggles visual highlighting of individual terms in the expression

parameters.name: Complexity
parameters.description: Determines the number of terms, use of exponents, and coefficient ranges

expressionGeneration.Medium: 3-5 terms, may include exponents up to ^3, coefficients 1-20

educationalStandards: CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.6.EE.A.2 - Write, read, and evaluate expressions in which letters stand for numbers
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.7.EE.A.1 - Apply properties of operations as strategies to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions

dublinCore.title: Integer Operations on the Number Line
creator: Dan McCreary
ChatGPT (GPT-5)
subject: Mathematics
Integers
Number Line
Arithmetic
dublinCore.description: An interactive p5.js simulation that visualizes integer addition and subtraction as movements on a horizontal number line. Users can click buttons to add or subtract values from -10 to +10, observing animated arrows and a cumulative equation.

learningObjectives: Visualize integer addition as movement to the right on a number line.
Visualize integer subtraction as movement to the left on a number line.
Interpret a cumulative arithmetic expression such as 0 + 3 - 2 + 4 = 5.
prerequisites: Understanding of positive and negative numbers

accessibility.screenReaderScript: Simulation that shows integer addition and subtraction as movement along a horizontal number line from -10 to +10. Blue circle shows current value, green arrows for addition, red arrows for subtraction.

controls.label: Add Buttons
controls.description: Adds positive integers (1–5) to the current position

controls.label: Subtract Buttons
controls.description: Subtracts positive integers (1–5) from the current position

controls.label: Reset
controls.description: Resets the simulation back to zero

visualElements.description: Horizontal number line from -10 to +10 with labeled tick marks
Green and red arrows animate integer addition and subtraction.

model.description: Integer arithmetic model representing cumulative addition and subtraction operations visualized as movements along a number line.
assumptions: Each operation changes the position by an integer step between -5 and +5.
Position range is clamped between -10 and +10.
limitations: Only supports integer values
Fixed range from -10 to +10

variables.name: currentPosition
variables.description: Current integer value on the number line

variables.name: equationParts
variables.description: String representation of the sequence of operations

events.name: operationPerformed
events.description: User clicked an Add or Subtract button

assessmentQuestions.question: If you start at -2 and add 4, what is your new position?
Explain why subtraction moves left on the number line.

extensions: Add sliders for variable step sizes
Include random problem generator for practice

title: Number Systems Hierarchy Diagram
description: An interactive Venn-style diagram showing how natural, whole, integer, rational, and real numbers are nested within each other, highlighting the position of irrational numbers.
subject: Mathematics - Number Systems
creator: Dan McCreary and Claude AI

name: Number Systems Diagram
description: Shows the nesting of number systems with clickable drill-down to sections in the Markdown page.

title: Number Types Venn Diagram
subject: Mathematics
description: An interactive Venn diagram that visualizes the hierarchical relationships between different types of numbers including Natural, Whole, Integers, Rational, Irrational, and Real numbers. Students can hover over regions to learn about each number type and see examples.
creator: Claude (Anthropic)
learningObjectives: Identify the hierarchical relationship between different number types
Understand that each inner set is a subset of the outer sets
Classify numbers into their appropriate categories
Recognize examples of each number type
Distinguish between rational and irrational numbers
prerequisites: Basic understanding of positive and negative numbers

controls.name: Show Labels
controls.description: Toggle visibility of number type labels

controls.name: Show Examples
controls.description: Toggle visibility of example numbers

controls.name: Hover Tooltips
controls.description: Hover over any region to see a detailed explanation of that number type

title: Prime Factorization Tree Builder
description: Interactive tool for building factor trees to find prime factorization of composite numbers through step-by-step visual construction.
subject: Mathematics
learningObjectives: Build factor trees to decompose composite numbers into prime factors
Identify and distinguish between prime and composite numbers
Understand that prime factorization is unique for each number (Fundamental Theorem of Arithmetic)
Apply divisibility rules to find factors efficiently
Express numbers in prime factorization form using exponential notation
bloomLevels: Remember: Recall prime numbers and divisibility rules
Understand: Explain the relationship between factors and prime factorization
Apply: Use divisibility rules to factor numbers systematically
Analyze: Compare different factorization paths leading to same result
Evaluate: Verify completeness and correctness of factorization
Create: Build complete factor trees for any composite number
prerequisites: Familiarity with prime and composite numbers
author: Claude (Anthropic AI)

controls.numberInput: Enter a number between 4 and 200 to factor
controls.randomNumber: Generate a random composite number at selected difficulty
controls.giveHint: Highlight a composite number and suggest divisibility rule
controls.showAnswer: Display the complete factorization tree with all prime factors
controls.clickNode: Click on blue (composite) nodes to enter two factors
controls.submitFactors: Validate and add factors to the tree

visualElements.edges: Lines connecting parent numbers to their factors
visualElements.primeList: Reference list of prime numbers up to 47
visualElements.divisibilityRules: Quick reference for divisibility by 2, 3, and 5

features: Show answer feature for complete factorization
pedagogicalApproach: Scaffolding through hints and reference materials
assessmentOpportunities: Predict prime factorization before building tree
Explain why different trees yield same factorization
Factor numbers with varying complexity
Identify patterns in factorizations
Apply divisibility rules efficiently
Compare factorization strategies
commonMisconceptions: Using 1 as a factor (prevented by validation)
Stopping factorization before reaching primes (visual feedback)
Entering incorrect factors (shake animation feedback)
Confusion about prime vs composite (color coding)
extensions: Compare different factorization paths for same number
Find GCF and LCM using prime factorizations
Explore perfect squares and their symmetric trees
Apply to finding square roots of perfect squares

technicalDetails.animations: shake on error, celebration on completion
technicalDetails.dataStructure: tree represented as nodes and edges

title: Variable Types Interactive Infographic
creator: Claude Code with microsim-p5 skill
subject: Mathematics
Algebra
Variable Notation
description: An interactive visual guide showing four common types of algebraic variables (position, time, counting, and rate) with real-world examples and expandable content in a 2x2 grid layout.
learningObjectives: Identify four main categories of variables used in algebra (position, time, counting, rate)
Explain the typical usage context for each variable type
Recognize conventional variable naming patterns in mathematical problems
Apply appropriate variable choices when setting up equations
prerequisites: Basic understanding of variables in algebra

controls.name: Card Hover
controls.description: Hover over any of the four category cards to see expanded descriptions
controls.purpose: Provides detailed context about variable usage

controls.name: Card Click
controls.description: Click on any card to toggle expanded view with additional examples
controls.purpose: Reveals 2-3 more real-world examples for each variable type

parameters.name: Category Colors
parameters.description: Blue for position, green for time, orange for counting, purple for rate variables

parameters.name: Expanded State
parameters.description: Tracks whether each card is showing additional examples

assumptions: Variables are presented in their most common conventional usage
Examples are simplified for educational clarity
Categories represent common patterns but are not exhaustive
limitations: Does not cover all possible variable types in mathematics
Context-specific usage may vary
Some variables can serve multiple purposes depending on context

assessmentOpportunities: Variable type identification
Context-appropriate variable selection
Creation of original examples
Recognition of mathematical conventions

progressive disclosure

software architecture

controls.description: Hover over each layer to see loading details

assumptions: Claude uses a three-level progressive disclosure system
Scripts can execute without loading into context
Frontmatter is always ~100 words
SKILL.md files are <5k words
limitations: Simplified representation of context management
Actual token counts may vary
Does not show runtime context changes

dublinCore.title: Cognitive Bias Recognition Quiz
dublinCore.creator: Dan McCreary
subject: Ethics
Critical Thinking
Cognitive Psychology
Data Literacy
dublinCore.description: An interactive quiz game that presents real-world scenarios and asks students to identify which cognitive bias is being demonstrated. Includes 8 scenarios covering cherry picking, availability heuristic, ad hominem bias, anchoring, framing effect, survivorship bias, confirmation bias, and correlation-causation fallacy.

learningObjectives: Identify common cognitive biases in realistic scenarios
Distinguish between similar biases such as cherry picking and confirmation bias
Explain why specific reasoning patterns qualify as biased thinking
Apply bias recognition skills to evaluate arguments and data presentations
prerequisites: Basic understanding of what cognitive biases are
Familiarity with concepts of evidence and argumentation

controls.name: Option buttons
controls.description: Four multiple choice buttons for selecting the identified bias

controls.name: Show Hint
controls.description: Displays a hint to help identify the bias (reduces points from 10 to 5)

controls.name: Explain
controls.description: Shows detailed explanation of why the answer is correct

controls.name: Next Scenario
controls.description: Advances to the next quiz scenario

controls.name: Restart Quiz
controls.description: Resets the quiz with randomized question order

assumptions: Each scenario demonstrates one primary cognitive bias
Distractor options are plausible but distinguishable from correct answer
limitations: Real-world scenarios may involve multiple overlapping biases
Quiz format cannot capture nuanced understanding

title: Data-Driven Ethics Process Flow
description: Interactive workflow diagram showing the six-step systematic process for data-driven ethical analysis: Identify, Quantify, Analyze, Map, Evaluate, and Target
subject: Ethics
creator: Claude AI with Mermaid Generator Skill

title: Leverage Points Iceberg
description: An interactive visualization of Donella Meadows' 12 Leverage Points using the iceberg metaphor. Surface interventions are visible but have low impact; deeper interventions are hidden but transformative.
creator: Dan McCreary
subject: Systems Thinking
Ethics
Policy Design
Leverage Points

educationalMetadata.topic: Donella Meadows' 12 Leverage Points for System Intervention
learningObjectives: Understand the hierarchy of intervention effectiveness in complex systems
Recognize why surface-level interventions often fail to create lasting change
Identify which leverage level is appropriate for different change strategies
Navigate to detailed explanations of each leverage point
educationalMetadata.prerequisites: Basic understanding of systems thinking concepts

accessibility.screenReader: Canvas description provided via describe() function
accessibility.colorContrast: High contrast text, zone colors distinguishable

controls.description: Hover over iceberg layers to see detailed information in the right panel
Click any layer to navigate to its detailed explanation in Chapter 6

visualElements.name: Iceberg
visualElements.description: Left side visualization showing 10 leverage point layers with animated waterline

visualElements.name: Info Panel
visualElements.description: Right side panel showing layer details on hover or introduction text by default

visualElements.name: Zone Legend
visualElements.description: Color-coded legend showing Shallow, Structural, Deep, and Transformative zones

assumptions: Leverage points are hierarchical with deeper points being more effective
The iceberg metaphor accurately represents visibility vs effectiveness tradeoff
limitations: Levels 2 and 3 are combined with Level 4 for simplicity
Actual effectiveness depends heavily on context and implementation

title: Area Formulas for Quadrilaterals
creator: Claude Code with microsim-p5 skill
subject: Geometry
description: A visual guide showing area formulas for six common quadrilaterals (rectangle, square, parallelogram, trapezoid, rhombus, and kite) with labeled diagrams and mathematical formulas in a responsive 2x3 grid layout.
learningObjectives: Students will remember area formulas for rectangles, squares, parallelograms, trapezoids, rhombuses, and kites
Students will understand how these formulas relate to the base rectangle formula
Students will identify the dimensions needed for each area formula
assumptions: All shapes are planar (2D)
Measurements are in consistent units
Formulas shown are for standard orientations
limitations: Does not perform calculations
Does not show derivations of formulas
No interactive manipulation of shapes

suggestedActivities: Discussion of how rectangle formula relates to others
assessmentOpportunities: Formula recall quizzes
Dimension labeling exercises
Area calculation problems

standardsAlignment: CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSG.GMD.A.1 - Give an informal argument for the formulas for the area of geometric figures

title: Collinear and Coplanar Points
description: A four-panel diagram showing examples and non-examples of collinear and coplanar point arrangements for geometry education.
creator: Dan McCreary
subject: Mathematics - Geometry
topic: Foundations of Geometry - Points, Lines, and Planes
learningObjectives: Analyze point arrangements to determine whether sets of points are collinear or coplanar
Distinguish between examples and non-examples of collinear points
Identify coplanar points in 2D and 3D representations
Understand that three or more points lying on the same line are always collinear
Recognize that four or more points may or may not be coplanar
prerequisites: Understanding of basic geometric terms (point, line, plane)

accessibility.description: Four-panel diagram showing examples and non-examples of collinear and coplanar points

assumptions: 2D representation of 3D concepts for panels 3 and 4
Grid lines help visualize planes in 2D space
limitations: Panel 4 uses perspective projection to represent 3D space in 2D
Static diagram without interactivity

title: Distance Formula Explorer
creator: AI-Generated MicroSim
subject: Mathematics
Geometry
Coordinate Geometry
Algebra
description: An interactive educational simulation that helps students visualize and apply the distance formula to find distances between two points on the coordinate plane, demonstrating the connection to the Pythagorean theorem through visual right triangles.

learningObjectives: Apply the distance formula to find distances between two points on a coordinate plane
Understand the connection between the distance formula and the Pythagorean theorem
Visualize the geometric relationship between horizontal distance, vertical distance, and diagonal distance
Calculate distances using both algebraic formulas and visual representations
Analyze how changing point positions affects distance and triangle dimensions
prerequisites: Familiarity with coordinate plane and plotting points

controls.name: Point A
controls.description: Blue draggable point representing the first coordinate (x₁, y₁)

controls.name: Point B
controls.description: Red draggable point representing the second coordinate (x₂, y₂)

controls.name: Show Right Triangle
controls.description: Toggles visibility of the right triangle formed by horizontal and vertical legs

controls.name: Show Calculation Steps
controls.description: Displays step-by-step calculation of the distance formula

controls.name: Snap to Grid
controls.description: Constrains dragged points to integer coordinates

controls.name: Random Points
controls.description: Generates random coordinates for both points within the grid range

controls.name: Point A Coordinates
controls.description: Manual entry fields for x₁ and y₁ coordinates

controls.name: Point B Coordinates
controls.description: Manual entry fields for x₂ and y₂ coordinates

visualElements: Coordinate grid with labeled axes (-10 to +10)
Two draggable colored points (blue for A, red for B)
Purple line showing distance between points
Optional gray right triangle with labeled legs
Real-time coordinate display for both points
Distance calculation display

assumptions: 2D Euclidean space
Grid range limited to -10 to +10 for clarity
Distances calculated in grid units
limitations: Does not extend to 3D coordinate systems
Limited to Cartesian coordinates (no polar coordinates)
Grid resolution fixed at integer precision when snapping enabled

assessmentOpportunities: Calculate specific distances given coordinates
Identify point pairs that create specific distances
Explain the relationship to Pythagorean theorem
Solve optimization problems (minimum distance scenarios)
differentiation: Snap to grid for beginners working with integers
Free positioning for advanced students working with decimals
Calculation steps toggle supports multiple learning paces
Random points provide unlimited practice opportunities
commonMisconceptions: Forgetting to square the differences before adding
Sign errors when working with negative coordinates
Confusing distance formula with slope formula
Not taking the square root of the sum

title: Koch Fractal
creator: Generated with Claude Code
subject: Mathematics
Geometry
Fractals
Computer Science
description: An interactive visualization demonstrating the iterative construction of the Koch curve, a classic fractal with self-similar patterns at every scale. Students can adjust the recursion level from 0 to 6 to observe how simple iterative rules create complex fractal patterns.

learningObjectives: Understand how simple iterative rules can create complex patterns
Explore the concept of self-similarity in fractals
Observe how mathematical infinity can be approached through finite iterations
Connect geometric transformations with fractal generation
Calculate fractal dimensions and understand dimensions beyond integers
prerequisites: Basic understanding of line segments and geometric transformations
Familiarity with the concept of iteration
Knowledge of equilateral triangles (helpful but not required)

controls.name: recursionSlider
controls.label: Recursion Level
controls.purpose: Controls the number of iterations in the Koch curve construction. Level 0 shows a straight line, while higher levels show increasingly complex fractal patterns.

variables: baselineY: Vertical position of the fractal baseline
canvasWidth: Responsive width of the drawing canvas
model.algorithm: Recursive Koch curve generation using geometric transformation
model.description: At each recursion level, every line segment is divided into three equal parts, and the middle third is replaced with two sides of an equilateral triangle. This process creates a self-similar fractal pattern.
equations: Length at level n: (4/3)^n × original length
Number of segments at level n: 4^n
assumptions: The fractal is displayed as a 2D projection
Maximum recursion level is limited to 6 for performance
Discrete rendering approximates the theoretical continuous curve
limitations: Does not show the full Koch snowflake (three curves arranged in a triangle)
Does not animate the iterative construction process
Performance may decrease at high recursion levels on slower devices

assessmentOpportunities: Pattern recognition at different recursion levels
Mathematical calculation of length and segments
Understanding of fractal dimension concept
Connection to real-world fractal examples
commonMisconceptions: Believing the curve will eventually smooth out
Thinking infinite length means infinite area
Confusion between recursion level and fractal dimension

references.title: On a Continuous Curve Without Tangent Constructible from Elementary Geometry
references.author: Helge von Koch
references.note: Original paper describing the Koch curve

references.title: The Fractal Geometry of Nature
references.author: Benoit Mandelbrot
references.note: Comprehensive introduction to fractals and their applications

title: Line Relationships in 3D
description: A 3D WebGL visualization demonstrating parallel, perpendicular, and skew line relationships in three-dimensional space using an interactive rotating box.
creator: Claude Code with microsim-p5 skill
subject: Mathematics
Geometry
Spatial Reasoning
learningObjectives: Identify parallel, perpendicular, and skew line relationships in 3D space
Distinguish between coplanar lines (parallel and perpendicular) and non-coplanar lines (skew)
Visualize how line relationships differ between 2D and 3D geometry
Apply knowledge of 3D line relationships to real-world structures
prerequisites: Understanding of basic line relationships in 2D (parallel and perpendicular)
Basic knowledge of angles and right angles

accessibility.description: 3D visualization with color-coded lines (blue for parallel, red for perpendicular, green for skew) and text labels

controls.label: Auto-rotate
controls.description: Enable or disable automatic rotation of the 3D box

controls.label: Rotation Speed
controls.description: Control the speed of automatic rotation

controls.label: Manual Rotation
controls.description: Click and drag to manually rotate the box in any direction

assumptions: Lines are represented by edges of a rectangular prism
Box is semi-transparent to allow viewing of all edges
Color-coding distinguishes different line relationships
limitations: Shows only three specific examples of each line relationship
Box shape constrains the types of line relationships shown
Does not calculate or display numerical measurements of angles or distances
visualElements: 3D rectangular prism (box) with transparent faces
Blue highlighted edges showing parallel lines with || symbol
Red highlighted edges showing perpendicular lines with ⊥ symbol and right angle indicator
Green highlighted edges showing skew lines with dashed distance line
Legend explaining all three line relationships
Text labels identifying each line (m, n, p, q, r, s)
educationalStandards: CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSG.CO.A.1 - Know precise definitions of line relationships
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.HSG.GMD.B.4 - Identify shapes in three dimensions

title: Make Lines Parallel
creator: AI-Generated MicroSim
subject: Mathematics
Geometry
Algebra
Coordinate Geometry
description: An interactive educational simulation where students drag a point to make two lines parallel by matching their slopes on a coordinate grid. Students receive immediate visual feedback through animation and color-coded messages.

learningObjectives: Understand that parallel lines have equal slopes
Apply the slope formula to determine if lines are parallel
Analyze how changing point positions affects line slope
Create parallel lines by manipulating coordinates on a grid
Evaluate whether two lines are parallel by comparing their slopes
prerequisites: Understanding of coordinate plane and plotting points
Knowledge of slope formula: m = (y₂ - y₁) / (x₂ - x₁)
Basic understanding of what parallel means
Ability to calculate rise and run

controls.name: Movable Red Point
controls.description: Red endpoint of the adjustable line that students drag to create parallel lines
controls.range: 0-10 on both x and y axes

controls.name: Check
controls.description: Verifies if the two lines are parallel by comparing slopes and triggers visual animation

controls.name: Reset
controls.description: Returns the movable point to its initial position

visualElements: 10×10 coordinate grid with 50-pixel spacing
Fixed blue line with two black endpoints
Adjustable blue line with one black fixed endpoint and one red movable endpoint
Animated green line during slope checking (2-second transition)
Color-coded feedback messages (green for correct, red for incorrect)
Grid border and reference lines

variables: Line 1 Point 1 coordinates (x₁, y₁) - fixed at (1, 7)
Line 1 Point 2 coordinates (x₂, y₂) - fixed at (7, 3)
Line 2 Point 1 coordinates (x₃, y₃) - fixed at (3, 6)
Line 2 Point 2 coordinates (x₄, y₄) - draggable, initially (5, 2)
assumptions: Lines are in 2D Euclidean space
Grid coordinates are integers (snap-to-grid enabled)
Vertical lines (undefined slope) are handled separately
Small tolerance (0.01) accounts for floating-point precision
limitations: Limited to 10×10 grid range
Only one line is adjustable (the other is fixed)
Does not handle vertical parallel lines explicitly
No support for lines outside the grid boundaries

pedagogy.instructionalStrategy: Interactive discovery learning with immediate feedback
assessmentOpportunities: Verify student can create parallel lines in multiple positions
Ask students to explain why certain positions create parallel lines
Calculate slopes manually and verify with the simulation
Predict whether lines will be parallel before checking
Explain the relationship between slope and parallelism
differentiation: Provide slope calculations for struggling students
Challenge advanced students to find equations of both lines
Use graph paper alongside simulation for visual learners
Ask advanced students to prove algebraically why slopes must match
Have struggling students start with horizontal lines (slope = 0)
commonMisconceptions: Thinking parallel lines must be the same length
Confusing slope with y-intercept
Believing any non-intersecting lines are parallel (only true in 2D plane)
Not understanding that multiple positions can create parallel lines
Calculating slope incorrectly (mixing up rise and run)

title: Points and Lines Explorer
creator: AI Assistant with Claude Code
subject: Geometry
Mathematics
Points and Lines
description: An interactive MicroSim for exploring fundamental geometric concepts of points, lines, and their relationships through hands-on manipulation. Students can create, move, and connect points to form lines, demonstrating that two points determine a unique line.

learningObjectives: Understand that a point represents a specific location in space
Recognize that two points determine exactly one line
Apply geometric notation for naming lines (e.g., line AB)
Explore properties of collinear and non-collinear points
Manipulate geometric objects to observe changing relationships

controls.name: Regenerate Random Points
controls.description: Creates a new random configuration with the number of points specified by the slider

controls.name: Mode Toggle
controls.description: Switches between Move Points mode (create/move) and Connect Points mode (draw lines)

controls.name: Add Point
controls.description: Adds a single point at a random location on the canvas

controls.name: Number of Points
controls.description: Controls how many points are generated when using the Regenerate button

modes.name: Move Mode
modes.description: Click anywhere to create new points, drag existing points to move them

modes.name: Connect Mode
modes.description: Click two points to create a line through them that extends infinitely in both directions

assumptions: Euclidean geometry on a 2D plane
Lines extend infinitely (represented by arrows)
Points are labeled sequentially from A-Z
limitations: 2D representation only (no 3D visualization)
Canvas boundaries limit visible portion of infinite lines
Labels wrap after 26 points (A-Z)

title: Point, Line, Plane - The Three Undefined Terms
creator: Dan McCreary
subject: Geometry
Mathematics
Undefined Terms
Foundational Concepts
description: A visual diagram MicroSim showing the three fundamental undefined terms of geometry (point, line, plane) with their properties, visual representations, and proper geometric notation. Features interactive toggle for annotations.

learningObjectives: Remember the three undefined terms of geometry (point, line, plane)
Understand visual representations and basic properties of undefined terms
Recognize proper geometric notation for naming points, lines, and planes
Distinguish between the three undefined terms based on their dimensional properties
prerequisites: Familiarity with coordinate systems (helpful but not required)

controls.name: Show Annotations
controls.description: Toggle display of detailed property annotations for each undefined term

panels.name: Point
elements: Additional example points (B, C, D, E)

simulationModel.modelType: Static visual diagram with interactive annotation toggle
concepts: Line: 1-dimensional infinite straight path with no thickness
Plane: 2-dimensional infinite flat surface with no thickness
visualFeatures: Multiple examples of proper geometric notation

keyQuestions: What are the three undefined terms of geometry?
How many dimensions does each undefined term have?
How do we name each of these geometric objects?
commonMisconceptions: Points have size (they don't—they only have position)
Lines have endpoints (they extend infinitely)
Planes have edges (they extend infinitely in all directions)
assessmentOpportunities: Identify undefined terms in real-world contexts
Name geometric objects using proper notation
Explain dimensional properties of each term
Distinguish between defined and undefined terms

dublin_core.title: Sierpinski Triangles
dublin_core.creator: Dan McCreary
subject: Mathematics
Geometry
Fractals
Recursion
Computer Science
dublin_core.description: An interactive visualization of the Sierpinski triangle fractal demonstrating recursive subdivision and self-similar patterns. Students can adjust the recursion depth from 0 to 7 levels to explore how simple rules create complex fractal patterns.

learning_objectives: Understand the concept of recursive subdivision in geometry
Analyze how fractals exhibit self-similarity at different scales
Explore the relationship between recursion depth and pattern complexity
Evaluate how mathematical infinity appears in finite visualizations
Calculate exponential growth in triangle counts (3^n)
prerequisites: Basic understanding of triangles and geometric shapes
Understanding of the concept of patterns

controls.label: Recursion Depth
controls.description: Controls the number of recursive subdivisions in the Sierpinski triangle pattern

parameters.name: currentDepth
parameters.purpose: Determines how many levels of recursion to apply when drawing the fractal

displays.label: Triangles
displays.description: Shows total number of triangles drawn (3^depth)

key_variables: recursionDepth - Number of recursive subdivisions to perform
vertices - Coordinates of triangle vertices for each recursion level
algorithm: - Create 4 smaller triangles from these midpoints
- Draw only the 3 outer triangles (skip center)
- Recursively apply to each of the 3 triangles
equations: Triangle count = 3^n where n is recursion depth
Total area approaches 0 as n approaches infinity
assumptions: Perfect geometric precision in subdivision
Equilateral starting triangle
Infinite recursion not practically achievable (limited to depth 7)
limitations: Performance degrades beyond depth 7 due to exponential triangle count
Does not show the mathematical properties of infinite recursion
Visual resolution limits ability to see very small triangles at high depths

ccss: CCSS.MATH.HSG.MG.A.1 - Use geometric shapes to model situations
CCSS.MATH.PRACTICE.MP7 - Look for and make use of structure
ngss: HS-ETS1-4 - Use mathematics and computational thinking

description: An interactive MicroSim demonstrating how sine and cosine values relate to a point moving around the unit circle, with corresponding graph visualization.
creator: Dan McCreary

title: Triangle Area Explorer
creator: Claude Code with microsim-p5 skill
subject: Geometry
description: An interactive exploration tool for understanding how base and height affect triangle area through the formula A = ½bh. Students manipulate sliders to adjust dimensions and observe real-time area calculations.
learningObjectives: Students will apply the triangle area formula A = ½bh to calculate areas with different dimensions
Students will analyze the relationship between base, height, and area
Students will understand that height must be perpendicular to the base
Students will predict how changing dimensions affects area
prerequisites: Understanding of units and square units

controls.name: Base Length Slider
controls.description: Adjusts the length of the triangle's base

controls.name: Height Slider
controls.description: Adjusts the perpendicular height of the triangle

controls.name: Reset Button
controls.description: Resets base and height to default values

parameters.name: triangleHeight
parameters.purpose: Perpendicular height from base to apex

assumptions: Triangle is drawn in 2D plane
Height is always perpendicular to base
Measurements use consistent arbitrary units
Triangle vertices remain within visible canvas
limitations: Does not show other triangle properties (angles, perimeter)
Limited to right-angle height visualization
Fixed scale factor for display
Does not cover triangle classification types

suggestedActivities: Pattern discovery: observe effects of doubling dimensions
Area challenge: find multiple base/height combinations for same area
Proportional reasoning: relationship between dimension and area changes
assessmentOpportunities: Calculate areas with given dimensions
Predict area changes from dimension changes
Identify base and height from triangle diagrams
Solve for unknown dimension given area and one dimension
commonMisconceptions: Height can be measured at any angle (must be perpendicular)
Area equals perimeter
Doubling both dimensions doubles area (actually quadruples)
Formula is bh instead of ½bh
discussionQuestions: Why is the formula ½bh instead of just bh?
What happens to area if you double both base and height?
Can two triangles with different dimensions have the same area?
How is triangle area related to rectangle area?

standardsAlignment: CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.6.G.A.1 - Find the area of triangles and polygons
CCSS.MATH.CONTENT.7.G.B.6 - Solve real-world problems involving area
